nodes.bodyText: It may not be necessary to do locking in this client since these changes are happening outside of Fedora in a temp file, so it seems unlikely for there to be conflicts within here.

At some point we should also add in read locking, so that it won't try to read while a write is being performed. I've created a followup ticket for doing this with the premis logger: https://jira.lib.unc.edu/browse/BXC-2722

Good work on this test. Do you know if it fails without the new pid locking code? It can sometimes be hard to trigger concurrency cases with a small number of requests.
It might be good to check the premis log after all the threads have completed to verify that all the expected events are present at once, just to make sure we end up with a merger of the two change sets at the end.
Its too bad we're using a mock binary transfer session in all these tests, so we aren't getting a test of currency in the write code, but judging by the comment on the mock we're probably stuck with it.

It would be more valuable to check that this event exists after the concurrent operations below take place, to show that the whole log makes it through. We can count on the other tests to already be making sure that normal addition of events works
At some point PID is going to become a interface, but this should be fine for now.

event1 and 2 here seem a little superfluous, seems like they are testing the same thing as the events from the loop. Maybe we should just have originalEvent and then all the events from the loop? It'd make the test a bit shorter and easier to understand what's being tested.
since the test isn't ever checking for the presence of this event, seems like we could probably remove it

i'm not sure this is showing that the read waited for the write, since we aren't verifying the read hasn't completed before the write
I think you would need to start the read and write threads at the same time, so set up threads in advance and then writeThread.start(); immediately followed by readThread.start();. You'd want to show that the read thread had not completed yet with premisNotes.size() == 0 before the writeThread.join();, and then that the event was present after.
In order to get the timing to work out reliably, in the writeThread you could do:

get a write lock for the object
start the writeEvents operation
sleep for 25ms
release the write lock
I forgot to add the sleep between starting the write and read threads.  It is no longer flapping locally.
This test looks good, my only suggestion is that this event seems unnecessary

Its not doing any harm, but you don't need to close the stream in this case. Most InputStream read operations close the stream, and this particular one specifies that it does so https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-io/javadocs/api-2.5/org/apache/commons/io/FileUtils.html#copyInputStreamToFile(java.io.InputStream,%20java.io.File)
It should be fine to remove this catch and just go directly to the finally
